bibl.title: Letter from Albert E. Truby to Philip Showalter Hench, October 24, 1940

div1.p: Truby comments on the validity of Agramonte's statements regarding Lazear's work.

div1.head: Letter from Albert E. Truby to Philip Showalter Hench, October 24, 1940

opener.dateline:
ALBERT E. TRUBY
145 LAUREL STREET
SAN FRANCISCO, CALIFORNIA
Oct. 24 / 40

div1.p:
Shortly after I sent my telegram
to you, approving of the way you quoted
me in your paper, I realized that I had
the date I gave you all wrong. Lazear
went to the Yf. hospital on Sept 19th 1900
and that was the day we gave the
house a thorough fumigation. We did
not disturb the contents of the house
until after his death of course-

I have enjoyed reading the last half
of your paper and think you were
right in quoting Miss Agramonte. While
I know it is not true I shall not
attempt to disprove his statements until
there is plenty of evidence to convince
the most sceptical. I know I could
convince you if I told you all
I know. I do hope you will come
out here sometime as you suggested
so I could tell you details I have
not written. Agramonte in his letter
to Finlay which you quoted, viz. “Lazear
produced the first two cases of y f. unknown
to the other members of the Board” and his
statement at the banquet in 1902, i.e. “performed
the first inocculations unknown to his
co workers”, are true and definately disprove
Ac
T
his Agramonte's later statements. The first two cases of
course were Carroll & Dean. With that in mind
read par. 3. & 4. on p. 26. of the Senate document.

I will be interested in the first section
of your paper and also in what went
on at W & J. when you have time to write
me- I shall continue to circulate that
carbon copy of my article among people
who were in Cuba and try to get
additional facts on criticisms. In that
way I think we will get more data
of value- When we have it all I will be
delighted to present it to you for your
library collection. Of course it will be
a pretty messy (It started out messy) mms., but at the same
time, more valuable & interesting I think.
I copy all the notes from that copy to the original, which is
on good paper, and in that way will have
a more legible copy when the time comes
to have it re-typed. I am glad that
you were interested in the story and hope
you will comment freely so that I can
have the benefit of your views. I feel
quite sure that the most of the dates and
much of the contents are correct, for almost
all of them are based on written statements
and therefore capable of checking.

I wanted to send you an air mail
letter before you left for W. & J. but did not
get time to do so-

I read. the 1938 Rheumatism Review, Thanks
would be much pleased to have the next one
and the Proceedings of the Clinics which you
so kindly offered to send me-
